"Bhutan witnessed the first of a kind lockdown to combat spread of coronavirus in the country on August 11. Today, 21 days on, we are confident to state that our lockdown measures have been successful.    (...) In an attempt to make the lockdown more endurable, while also streamlining the processes, many initiatives were introduced over the weeks to ease lockdown. It included allowing individual movement within the zones and gewogs, among others.    Learning from experience, this will now be recorded in the lockdown stages, the document of which will be shared with public soon.    The unlocking episode is being considered in three phases, spreading over a total of ten days from September 1-10.    Phase one of unlocking (September 1-3) will allow more relaxation of essential activities, opening of more designated shops and restaurants, while allowing families to walk in super-zones. Further easing will be carried out in phase two (September4-6), as movement public transport within the dzongkhags will be encouraged.    In the final phase (September 7) of unlocking, private car movements will be allowed. Starting 5am, September 11, movement of vehicles beyond the district is allowed but with prior permission from Royal Bhutan Police."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201107220746/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/31-08-20-press-release-pmo/

A government press release on the 31st of August advises:  "Meanwhile, the government appeals to all public to follow COVID-19 norms at all times. Wearing of facemask is compulsory. Please observe physical distance and all health advisories."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201106234120/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/31-08-20-press-release-pmo/

Bhutan begins its phased unlocking, but schools remain closed at this stage.    "All schools, colleges and institutes will remain closed while the government will carefully assess and prepare for the reopening starting tomorrow [general phased unlocking].  "Health experts will assess the situation after 10 days. For schools, should the situation favour, classes IX and XI will also be opened along with classes X and XII."   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210320223950/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/01-09-20-the-phase-wise-unlocking-activities-pmo/

"Bhutan witnessed the first of a kind lockdown to combat spread of coronavirus in the country on August 11. Today, 21 days on, we are confident to state that our lockdown measures have been successful.    (...) The unlocking episode is being considered in three phases, spreading over a total of ten days from September 1-10. Phase one of unlocking (September 1-3) will allow more relaxation of essential activities, opening of more designated shops and restaurants, while allowing families to walk in super-zones. Further easing will be carried out in phase two (September4-6), as movement public transport within the dzongkhags will be encouraged. In the final phase (September 7) of unlocking, private car movements will be allowed. Starting 5am, September 11, movement of vehicles beyond the district is allowed but with prior permission from Royal Bhutan Police.    "(...) The following activities are not applicable to higher risk areas that include Phuentsholing, Gelephu, Samtse and Samdrupjongkhar.  The areas are determined by zoning arrangements, where the unlocking will take place in more sustained manner. Local taskforces will share the updates as and when required."    Note: The lockdown has not been lifted in high risk areas hence 3T code.    Sources: https://archive.vn/VkPRe  http://web.archive.org/web/20201107230242/https://www.facebook.com/MoFABhutan/posts/1240612359618551

Public gathering    – No social events like birthday, wedding, promotions, official dinners and functions will be allowed until further notice.  – Cremation and funeral rites will be limited to close family circles, as authorised by the local authorities.  – No outdoor activities like picnic, hiking, visiting spiritual sites are allowed in this period." "The Druk Gyalpo’s Relief Kidu for affected individuals will continue from July until September 2020. However, as announced on April 30, 2020, the amounts are revised to Nu 10,000 and Nu 7,000 per month respectively, in anticipation of rising number of applicants.    Kidu recipients are encouraged to actively seek employment opportunities through various  government and private led initiatives. The Relief Kidu has granted about Nu 700 million to over 23,000 affected people between April and June 2020, boosting their morale and providing critical livelihood support and assurances of hope amid current hardships."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200723012056/https://www.cabinet.gov.bt/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/PR-Phase-2-fiscal-and-monetary-measured.pdf

"06/09/20: Unlocking Phase III    (...) Starting 5am tomorrow, movement of private vehicles, in addition to the public transportations, is allowed but strictly within the district."    Source:https://archive.vn/w9Xpj#selection-411.0-411.29

"Lockdown relaxation in the red zone town of Phuentsholing started from eight in the morning yesterday (September 8). The lockdown will be relaxed in five phases.    Starting yesterday, until tomorrow, a resident from each household has been allowed movement using the movement permit, in the respective zones in the specific given time, according to the Southern Covid-19 Task Force (SC19TF) in Phuentsholing.    Between September 11 and September 13, families will be allowed to move, without movement permit across the zones. Designated shops and restaurants (for takeaways only) will also be allowed during this time. Hardware shops and automobile workshops, including the earlier identified essential shops will also be opened."    Note: In the other three red-zones indicated in the last press release the lockdown is still in place hence the 3T code.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201107231803/https://kuenselonline.com/lockdown-relaxation-starts-in-phuentsholing/

All inter-district movements are allowed from 'September 11, with prior registration. Registration portals are being created, which will be announced soon. It will include online registration, help-line calls and physical registration at identified offices or nearest check posts as you travel.'    https://archive.vn/w9Xpj

"Lockdown lifting in Gelephu to begin tomorrow (September 12)    Over two weeks since Gelephu last detected a Covid-19 positive case from a frontline worker, the task force is readying to lift the lockdown phase-wise from Saturday.    The dzongkhag Covid-19 task force has readied the proposal for the relaxation of the lockdown and submitted the plan to the southern region Covid-19 taskforce.    (...) He added that the lifting of lockdown could differ from other dzongkhags because the town shares a long porous border with the Indian state of Assam where the Covid-19 case is on the rise.    The shops for essential items, restaurants with delivery service, and bars would be allowed to open but must adhere to specific timing.    Task force officials and the technical advisory group said people should take safety protocols seriously as part of new normal."    Note: In the remaining two red-zones indicated in the last press release the lockdown has not been lifted hence the 3T code.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201107232136/https://kuenselonline.com/lockdown-lifting-in-gelephu-to-begin-tomorrow/

"In order to prevent and contain the spread of COVID-19 and to minimize social and economic disruption, the four key interventions namely; Testing, Tracing, Treating and behavioural change is being implemented.     While testing, tracing and treating is being carried out by the Government, behavioural change is solely the responsibility of each one of us. As we know that the virus is here to stay and we should learn to live with it by adapting the new normal in our daily lives, we should ultimately know that ‘behavioural change’ is our Gyenkhu to have a better and healthier environment to live in."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201107142516/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/15-09-20-community-transmission-mitigation-strategy-moh/    "The government has developed contact tracing app called “Druk Trace” mobile app.    The app is to be used for “Contact Tracing” by helping with the identification of people who may have come in direct contact with a COVID-19 infected person while visiting public places or while using public transportation.    Therefore in order to prevent local transmission of the virus in the country, every office, business entity, public transport (taxis and buses) are required to publicly display a QR code generated from the Druk Trace App.    Similarly all individuals are mandated to use the Druk Trace app to scan the QR code every time they enter these public places or use public transportation. Those who do not have smartphones will be required to provide contact information to be filled in the log files that are to be managed by the respective offices and drivers."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201012215516/http://www.moh.gov.bt/contact-tracing-app/

"(...) the DC19TF is please to notify the general public that the Final Phase of the Unlocking of the Dzongkhag which is a revision of the Relaxation of lockdown Phase IV notified earlier shall come into effect  from September 18th onwards."    Note: In Samdrupjongkha the lockdown has not been lifted yet hence the 3T code.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201107233056/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/16-09-20-unlocking-for-samtse-dzongkhag-administration-samte/

The last of the four high risk areas began the unlocking activities of the dzongkhag in a phase-wise manner on October 20 (see C6).    "In the first phase – September 20-22, individuals and families will be allowed to come out from their homes from all the zones. People would be only allowed to walk or cycle all the zones and people would also be allowed to visit the hospital between 10am to noon using their health book. According to a press release from the Covid-19 task force, all grocery and pharmaceutical shops would be allowed to open. Identified restaurants and bars providing  delivery  services can also open. However, no sit-in dining would be allowed. All shops must close at 6pm. Local manufacturing units would also be allowed to operate on the condition that they are in a self-contained facility without movement of workers. Construction activities  can also resume but the activities must be limited within the premises, workers should stay at the site, and their rations should be provided by the contractors. In the second phase of the unlocking, which starts from September 23-25, movement of public transports including taxis within the dzongkhag would be allowed. However, they are allowed to carry only 50 percent of the full capacity. Shops such as stationary, mobiles, hardware, automobile workshops and electronic, among others, would open. All shops can remain open until 7pm. In the third phase beginning September 26-28, movements of private vehicles within the dzongkhag would be allowed with 50 percent of the permissible passengers. All offices and shops would be opened with the Covid-19 safety protocols while transportation of raw materials to the worksite would also be allowed. All shops and business entities can remain open until 8pm."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201107233920/https://kuenselonline.com/samdrupjongkhar-lifts-lockdown/    "The unlocking episode is being considered in three phases, spreading over a total of ten days from September 1-10.     Phase one of unlocking (September 1-3) will allow more relaxation of essential activities, opening of more designated shops and restaurants, while allowing families to walk in super-zones. Further easing will be carried out in phase two (September 4-6), as movement public transport within the dzongkhags will be encouraged. In the final phase (September 7) of unlocking, private car movements will be allowed. Starting 5am, September 11, movement of vehicles beyond the district is allowed but with prior permission from Royal Bhutan Police.    (...)  2. Workplaces    – Starting September 7, all offices should open and operate fulltime.  – Until then, management should prepare for offices to operate within the COVID-19 norms. Strict physical distancing at workplaces should be ensured and options to “work from home” or in shifts should introduced.    3. Business entities    – Additional shops catering to essentials like grocery and pharmaceutical can open. However, shopkeepers must continue to practice the COVID-19 safety protocols. Given the associated risk, the government recommends opening of shops only if necessary.  – Only those eateries and restaurants that have delivery or take-away services can tomorrow. There should not be any sit-in customers at all times.  – All business entities must close by 9pm.    (...)  6. Construction    – Construction works will be allowed. However, activities must be limited within the premises, workers must live at site, and their ration and essentials should be provided for.  – Transport of raw materials to worksites will be allowed only after the third day, when movement of vehicles with are permitted."    " 10/09/20: Press Release on the completion of the Unlocking period – PMO    Business entities    1. All shops can open but must ensure proper spacing and other COVID-19 etiquettes.    2. Eateries and restaurants can allow sit-in customers but must not exceed 50 percent of the capacity at a given time. However, everyone is encouraged to opt for delivery and take-away services.    3. Barber shops and salons can operate but must ensure 50 percent of the capacity and enforce strict COVID-19 practices considering the heightened risk. Video game parlors and snookers can also operate at 50 percent capacity.    4. Informal businesses and street vendors can operate. They must wear facemasks and follow food safety procedures.    (...) Activities that don’t feature in this press release are being reviewed and announcements will be made accordingly."    Note: This press release includes nationwide measures hence the 2G coding. In the high risk areas that have completed the lockdown the measures implemented have been the same.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201109003511/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/31-08-20-press-release-pmo/  http://web.archive.org/web/20201108001020/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/10-09-20-press-release-on-the-completion-of-the-unlocking-period-pmo/

"After about 41 days, Samdrupjongkhar dzongkhag began the unlocking activities of the dzongkhag in a phase-wise manner (...)"    In the first phase – September 20-22, individuals and families will be allowed to come out from their homes from all the zones. People would be only allowed to walk or cycle all the zones and people would also be allowed to visit the hospital between 10am to noon using their health book.    (...) In the second phase of the unlocking, which starts from September 23-25, movement of public transports including taxis within the dzongkhag would be allowed. However, they are allowed to carry only 50 percent of the full capacity. People can visit the hospital using their private vehicles. Shops such as stationary, mobiles, hardware, aumobile workshops and electronic, among others, would open. All shops can remain open until 7pm.    In the third phase beginning September 26-28, movements of private vehicles within the dzongkhag would be allowed with 50 percent of the permissible passengers. Movement of cars outside the dzongkhag would also be permitted with prior permission from the RBP and Road Safety and Transport Authority (RSTA)."    One of the 6 common new normal preventive measures listed by the government is to stay at home and come out on when necessary (hence the 2G code).    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201107221916/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/28-09-20-travel-requisite-moh/  http://web.archive.org/web/20201107233920/https://kuenselonline.com/samdrupjongkhar-lifts-lockdown/

"After about 41 days, Samdrupjongkhar dzongkhag began the unlocking activities of the dzongkhag in a phase-wise manner starting yesterday (September 20).    (...) In the second phase of the unlocking, which starts from September 23-25, movement of public transports including taxis within the dzongkhag would be allowed. However, they are allowed to carry only 50 percent of the full capacity.    People can visit the hospital using their private vehicles."    "4. Buses are allowed to ferry passengers up to 50 percent of the capacity.  5. Taxis are allowed to carry maximum of three passengers at a time. Two at the back, one in front.  6. Private cars must carry only 50 percent of the capacity, unless they are all family members." (These measures are to be implemented on a national level)    Note: The lockdown has been lifted in all the four red-zones hence 1G.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201107233920/https://kuenselonline.com/samdrupjongkhar-lifts-lockdown/  http://web.archive.org/web/20201108001020/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/10-09-20-press-release-on-the-completion-of-the-unlocking-period-pmo/

Note: No information about other public events taking place was found hence 2G code (it seems that in general all other events e.g. sporting events remain cancelled).    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201108003606/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/28-09-20-national-situational-update-on-covid-19-moh/

"(...) Schools, colleges and institutes:    1. Classes X and XII will resume from September 14, and Classes IX and XI will also start on-campus school from September 21. Those classes in high risk areas will have to wait until the unlocking procedures are complete in those places.  2. Technical and vocational training institutes, including private driving and tailoring courses, can resume.  3. While colleges can reopen, the Royal University of Bhutan will announce the details."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201106130011/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/10-09-20-press-release-on-the-completion-of-the-unlocking-period-pmo/    "20/09/20: Unlocking for Samdrup Jongkhar – Dzongkhag Administration, Samdrup Jongkhar    (...) Students of Classes IX to XII shall resume their classes from September 28, 2020."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201109013309/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/20-09-20-unlocking-for-samdrup-jongkhar-dzongkhag-dzongkhag-administration-samdrup-jongkhar/    Note: (See C6) All the higher risk areas indicated by the Government in the press release on August 31 have completed the lockdown procedures which is why I have downgraded it to a 2G.

The Government of Bhutan does not recommended any non-essential travel should be avoided, given the uncertain situation. If it is absolutely necessary, there are a number of requirements for intercity/interstate travel. These include mandatory registration, quarantine and testing in some cases, depending on whether travels are going to/coming from low risk or high risk areas.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201107221916/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/28-09-20-travel-requisite-moh/

"We request the general public to continue abiding with the preventive measures such as maintaining wearing face masks, physical distancing, avoiding gatherings (...)"    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201014202741/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/02-10-20-highlights-from-the-press-brief-moh/

Bhutan has been running the main country awareness through its various websites, but also an official Facebook platform where the residents can get up to date information.     Sources (examples): http://web.archive.org/web/20201107143104/https://www.facebook.com/MoHBhutan  http://web.archive.org/web/20201107143227/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20201107143342/http://www.moh.gov.bt/update-our-gyenkhu-5/
Everyone visiting flu clinics will be tested on COVID 19: https://web.archive.org/web/20201014202741/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/02-10-20-highlights-from-the-press-brief-moh/

"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs would like to inform that an Air Travel Bubble Arrangement has been agreed between the Royal Government of Bhutan and the Government of India on 18th September 2020 to enable flight operations between the two countries till the resumption of normal International flights between the two countries.    Drukair operated its first flight under this arrangement to Bagdogra on 1 October 2020. Hereafter, Drukair will operate 1 flight each to Delhi and Kolkata, and one flight to Bagdogra/Guwahati a week as follows:    1. Paro-Kolkata-Paro on 16th October 2020 (thereafter every Friday)  2. Paro-Delhi-Paro on 19th October 2020 (thereafter every Monday)    Bhutan Airlines also intends to begin operations in the near future.    Travellers will be subject to strict adherence to the mandatory quarantine and other COVID-19 related health protocols put in place by the Royal Government of Bhutan and the Government of India."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201106183916/https://www.mfa.gov.bt/?p=8389    According to the information available on Drukair's Facebook page there are limited flights to/from Thailand.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201106184010/https://www.facebook.com/Drukair/

The Druk Gyalpo’s Relief Kidu for affected individuals ended in September 2020. ´    Note: No new measures were found, on the website of the Ministry of Finance, hence the change of coding.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20200723012056/https://www.cabinet.gov.bt/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/PR-Phase-2-fiscal-and-monetary-measured.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20201015044532/https://www.cabinet.gov.bt/

"(...) tax payments, for tourism and related sectors (hotel, airlines and tour operators) are deferred until December 31, 2020, while for other sectors until September 30, 2020; deferred payment of sales tax and customs duty on essential items (March to June 2020); waiver of payment of rent and other charges (April-December 2020) by tourism-related business entities leasing government properties, deferral of electricity charges payment for industry (till December 2020) (...). As of May 25, the government will be refunding the 5 percent sales tax collected on telecom services collected on or after January 16, 2020. The government is mobilizing additional resources such as grants and concessional borrowing as well as bilateral and in-kind financing to support capital spending. Investments in GovTech is allowing Bhutan to reap benefits during COVID-19 including fast disbursement of cash relief funds. In late September, the first sovereign offering of a 3-year domestic bond of US$ 41 million (or Nu. 3 billion) at 6.5 per cent was issued to support increasing fiscal needs."    "On October 5, the government launched the National Credit Guarantee Scheme (NCGS), to boost investments of both small and medium enterprise, by providing collateral requirement relief and a substantial credit guarantee. Effective April 14, Phase I monetary relief measures were introduced by the RMA. Many of these measures were extended under Phase II (July 8), including the waiver of interest on loans (until September 2020) and partial waiver (until March 2021), extension of deferred monthly loan instalment repayment (until June 2021), granting financial institutions the provision of bridging loans as concessional term-based loan (5% interest rate for the tenure of the loan) for CIT and BIT filing business agencies, conversion of concessional working capital soft loans to tourism (...) extension of soft loans to cottage and small industries through the CSI Development Bank (microloans at 2 percent interest for agriculture and rural activities and working capital loans at 4 percent interest rate) by 12 months to June 2021."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201106230216/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Revised advisory (October 8)    -Buses are allowed to carry passengers at 50 percent capacity;  -Private cars are allowed to carry passengers at 50 percent capacity (unless family members)  -Taxis are allowed to carry 3 passengers.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201022030512/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/08-10-20-revised-travel-advisory-moh/

One of the 6 common new normal preventive measures listed by the government is to stay at home and come out on when necessary.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201012213728/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/08-10-20-revised-travel-advisory-moh/

The revised travel advisory, from October 8, reiterates the importance of avoiding non-essential interstate/intercity travel, given the uncertain situation. If it is absolutely necessary, there are a number of requirements on intercity/interstate travel, which are similar to those from the previous travel advisory (including mandatory registration, quarantine and testing in some cases, depending on whether travels are going to/coming from low risk or high risk areas).     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201012213728/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/08-10-20-revised-travel-advisory-moh/

No changes to school closure. Only students of grades IX, X, XI and XII across the country are back to school since September 21. See UNICEF website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20201022022845/https://www.unicef.org/bhutan/stories/and-then-schools-reopened%E2%80%A6

On the revised advisory on  October 8, passenger requirement for bus, taxi and family car are put into place. 50% requirement for bus and family car. Taxi is up to max 3 person. See Bhutan government website, archived.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201022030512/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/08-10-20-revised-travel-advisory-moh/

On the revised advisory on  October 8, mask is required at all time. See Bhutan government website, archived.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201022030512/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/08-10-20-revised-travel-advisory-moh/

Schools for Classes PP to VIII will reopen for the academic session in February next year,  the education ministry announced.     Reference articles:  http://www.education.gov.bt/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Notificcation-on-reopening-of-schools-for-2021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20201102122243/https://kuenselonline.com/education-ministry-announces-school-reopening-dates/

1. All social events are discouraged. Unavoidable ones should be limited to family members.  2. Cremation and funeral rites, and other rituals at home are permitted but without gathering.  3. Official meetings, seminars, workshops and travels are not allowed.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201108001020/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/10-09-20-press-release-on-the-completion-of-the-unlocking-period-pmo/    1. Sports facilities like gym, yoga, dance studios and rubber tracks can operate at 50 percent capacity.    2. Non-contact sports of athletics and golf, and partial contact sports of badminton, tennis and table tennis are allowed.    3. Given the engagement for fitness among people, all futsal, football turfs and basketball courts, including private, can operate. However, there should not be any spectators at any time.    4. Archery may be played, subject to not more than 15 participants. No spectators are allowed.    5. The business closure time of 9pm will not apply to sports.    6. Parks and public places can open with strict monitoring of crowd.

Bhutan’s borders are currently closed to foreign nationals, including British citizens. Foreigners, with the exception of citizens from India, Bangladesh and the Maldives nationals, may only enter or depart the country through certain towns such as Phuntsoling, Samdrup Jongkhar and Gelephug (by road) or Paro (by air).    http://web.archive.org/web/20201208100644/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bhutan/entry-requirements

The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grant for individuals directly affected by the pandemic and full interest waiver on loans contracted since April 10, 2020 until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waiver will continue until March 2021.  Investments in GovTech is allowing Bhutan to reap benefits during COVID-19 including fast disbursement of cash relief funds.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208102716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  The Druk Gyalpo’s Relief Kidu was launched on 14 April 2020 to provide income support to individuals whose livelihoods were affected because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Between April and September 2020, Nu.1.2 billion was granted to over 33,000 beneficiaries and over 14,000 children.    The Relief Kidu has been extended for three months, from October to December 2020. Individuals who applied for or received Kidu in Phase I and/or Phase II need to re-apply for further assessments. Applications are also open to new applicants who have been displaced by the coronavirus pandemic.  Who is eligible?  Bhutanese who have been displaced by the coronavirus pandemic and are currently residing in Bhutan are eligible for the Druk Gyalpo’s Relief Kidu. The displaced group includes those who have been laid off, placed on unpaid leave or on reduced pay from businesses *** as well as self-employed individuals *** who have lost their earnings either partially or completely.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208103817/https://royalkidu.bt/

Business Income tax (BIT) and Corporate Income tax (CIT) filing for the income year 2019 was deferred until June 30, 2020 and tax payments, for tourism and related sectors (hotel, airlines and tour operators) are deferred until December 31, 2020, while for other sectors until September 30, 2020; deferred payment of sales tax and customs duty on essential items (March to June 2020); waiver of payment of rent and other charges (April-December 2020) by tourism-related business entities leasing government properties, deferral of electricity charges payment for industry (till December 2020), free electricity and wi-fi services to hotels serving as quarantine facility (July-September 2020). As of May 25, the government will be refunding the 5 percent sales tax collected on telecom services collected on or after January 16, 2020.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201208102716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

There is a registration for vulnerable people available on the government site http://www.moh.gov.bt/  This article details the measures currently in place for elderly people  Standardization of elderly services in hospitals, all elderly people will be provided basic screening for NCDs while visiting health facilities irrespective of illness, tele-consultation for elderly folks during lockdown, refilling for elderly folks during lockdown, relocation plan for elderly folks to safer places, essential services package for vulnerable groups    Since the measures described in the source are not in line with "narrow restrictions" but more geared towards enabling the recommendations to elderly (stay at home, visit hospital under protections etc.) to actually be carried out, downgraded to 1G on review.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208110124/http://www.moh.gov.bt/update-a-message-from-honble-sowai-lyonpo-in-commemoration-of-the-international-day-for-older-persons-2020/

This is to update the public that the lockdown is extended to the super zones, which includes Thimphu throm and peripheral areas of Debsi, RTC area, Gangchey, Nyezergang in the south, Kabesa, Begana and Changtagang in the north. Until further notice, all shops, offices, schools and institutions in the Thimphu Super Zone must remain closed. This is a complete lockdown and there will be no delivery of essentials for now. The first consignment of the vaccine will arrive in the country very soon.  The plan is to vaccinate all the people together, so we will roll out the nationwide vaccination program only when we have sufficient doses for all the targetted population.  Once we have the required number of doses, our plan is to vaccinate the entire population in their respective communities, gewogs and chiwogs in one week. We are well on track with health facilities and human resource planning. That time, movement of people will be stopped for one week.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/18-01-21-%f0%9d%90%92%f0%9d%90%9a%f0%9d%90%a5%f0%9d%90%a2%f0%9d%90%9e%f0%9d%90%a7%f0%9d%90%ad-%f0%9d%90%a9%f0%9d%90%a8%f0%9d%90%a2%f0%9d%90%a7%f0%9d%90%ad%f0%9d%90%ac-%f0%9d%90%9f%f0%9d%90%ab/

All schools will open as scheduled by the education ministry. Random testing for students and teachers will be carried out every two weeks. Health focal persons have been identified to monitor compliance and surveillance on campus.  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/

All offices and institutions to open. The COVID-19 Safety focal office in all offices must ensure that all COVID-19 norms are in place and implemented.  All shops, restaurants and business entities can open.  The closure time is 9pm.  For hair saloons and barber shops, extra precaution to maintain proper hygiene and safety protocols will be imposed.  Mandatory COVID-19 testing every two weeks will be carried out.  Opening of entertainment centers of movie halls, clubs, karaokes and drayangs will be announced at a later date.  All sporting activities are allowed but without any spectators.  Closure time is 11pm.  No tournaments are allowed, unless approved by the Bhutan Olympic Committee.  For traditional games of archery and khuru, only 10 participants are allowed at a time.  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/

While gathering of any sort is discouraged, for community based religious congregation, a maximum of 25 people can participate. Prior approval must be sought from the local taskforce.  Religious gatherings at home must be limited to family members.  For funeral rites to be restricted to close circles.  Pilgrimage, menchu, tsachu and hiking are allowed.  For conferences, seminars, workshops and training, a maximum of only 25 people are allowed to gather.  The COVID-19 safety focal officers must maintain proper record of the attendees.  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/

(Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/

Inter-dzongkhag movement is allowed.  Public transports such as buses and taxis can operate.  Quarantine requirement from Thimphu and Paro is being lifted.  Seven-day mandatory quarantine will continue for those travelling from high risk to low risk areas.  All travellers must register with Check Post Management System (CPMS) prior to their travel.  Besides random testing of travellers along the check points, the public transport drivers will have to undergo mandatory testing every two weeks  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/

the battle is only half won as we continue to sail through the pandemic, that too amid peak winter. We could regress into a situation far more disastrous if we let our guards down today.  Therefore, concerted efforts are being made to heighten surveillance along the borders and entry points with enhanced vigilance and improved operating procedures.  More tests for COVID-19 will be conducted among business communities, drivers, frontliners, students and health workers, while flu clinics will always scan for the early signs of the disease. Additional mobile flu clinics will be introduced in busy public places and certain points along the highways.  Above all, we are anticipating the roll out of the nationwide COVID-19 vaccination program that will protect our people and enable us to prevent the outbreak of the disease as we venture forward.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/

All movie theatres, snooker rooms and video parlours should be closed.   All business entities must adjust timing and engage employees in a way that there is no crowding.  All business entities must ensure and make it conducive for their customers maintain physical distance. Agencies will have to devise and institute “work from home” system.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210330091444/https://kuenselonline.com/press-release-from-prime-ministers-office/

Gatherings for religious purposes are discouraged, prompted by the fact that countries have experienced outbreaks from such events.   Gathering at any social events like birthday, wedding or promotion are disallowed.   Picnics or similar outdoor functions are prohibited.  All congregations at work, official dinners, functions or gatherings at workplace eateries are discouraged.   Individuals are required to maintain physical distance from the rest at grocery outlets, vegetable markets, fuel depots or other public places.   While in queue to avail of services like banking or hospital, individuals are required to maintain physical distance.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210330091444/https://kuenselonline.com/press-release-from-prime-ministers-office/

Travel RestrictionsBhutanese authorities continue to ban the entry of foreign nationals. International flights to and from Bhutan remain severely limited due to travel restrictions on Bhutanese citizens and carriers, as well as border closures. Limited international flights are operational, though flight schedules are subject to change at short notice.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517023838/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/476926/bhutan-authorities-banning-nonessential-activity-in-phuentsholing-and-samdrup-jongkhar-as-of-may-11-update-27

The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grant for individuals directly affected by the pandemic.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517024737/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Full interest waiver on loans contracted since April 10, 2020 until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waiver will continue until March 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517024737/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No update in policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517023838/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/476926/bhutan-authorities-banning-nonessential-activity-in-phuentsholing-and-samdrup-jongkhar-as-of-may-11-update-27

As of May 31, Bhutan continues to ban nonessential activity and movements in multiple areas. Although authorities have relaxed some controls in Samdrup Jongkhar and Samtse District, officials maintain restrictions in Phuentsholing and parts of Trashigang District. Government officials may enact similar curbs in other areas, mainly in urban centers and other southern border districts of Chukha, Dagana, Pemagatshel, Sarpang, and Zhemgang  http://web.archive.org/web/20210531144919/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/485206/bhutan-authorities-maintaining-controls-in-high-risk-areas-as-of-may-31-due-to-covid-19-activity-update-29

Inter-district travelers must register via the Check Post Management System. Prior approval is necessary for movement from any high-risk area to a low-risk one; travelers from any designated high-risk area must undergo a seven-day quarantine. India has already supplied around 5.5 lakh vaccine doses to Bhutan in two batches. And, roughly 80% of adults in the Himalayan country have been vaccinated with the first dose. Bhutan had said that it would fully vaccinate the entire country by the end of June. However, vaccine crunch in India might delay Bhutan's plan for 100% immunization. Earlier this month, Bhutanese Foreign Minister Tandi Dorji said the Indian government had assured Bhutan that it would provide the half-million AstraZeneca vaccines, known as Covishield in India, required for the second dose to achieve full immunization.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210531151256if_/https://www.livemint.com/news/india/india-requires-more-covid-vaccines-will-not-exert-pressure-for-supply-bhutan-11621693513156.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210531151256if_/https://www.livemint.com/news/india/india-requires-more-covid-vaccines-will-not-exert-pressure-for-supply-bhutan-11621693513156.html

As of June 14, Bhutan continues to ban nonessential activity and movements in Phuentsholing and Thimphu. Authorities have relaxed some controls in Samdrup Jongkhar, Samtse and Trashigang districts, allowing intra-district movement and limited commercial activities. Government officials may enact enhanced curbs in other areas, mainly in urban centers and other southern border districts of Chukha, Dagana, Pemagatshel, Sarpang, and Zhemgang.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614170819/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/490106/bhutan-authorities-maintaining-controls-in-high-risk-areas-including-thimphu-as-of-june-14-due-to-covid-19-activity-update-30  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614170757/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-06-21-lockdown-in-thimphu/

As of June 14, Bhutan continues to ban nonessential activity and movements in Phuentsholing and Thimphu. Authorities have relaxed some controls in Samdrup Jongkhar, Samtse and Trashigang districts, allowing intra-district movement and limited commercial activities. Government officials may enact enhanced curbs in other areas, mainly in urban centers and other southern border districts of Chukha, Dagana, Pemagatshel, Sarpang, and Zhemgang. Other nationwide measures continue. Several recreational venues, such as movie theaters, dance clubs, and nightclubs, remain closed nationwide. The use of facemasks is compulsory in public places. Authorities also require residents to use the Druk Trace application for contact tracing when entering public places, business premises, and public and private hire transport vehicles  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614170819/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/490106/bhutan-authorities-maintaining-controls-in-high-risk-areas-including-thimphu-as-of-june-14-due-to-covid-19-activity-update-30  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614170757/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/12-06-21-lockdown-in-thimphu/

Authorities have relaxed some controls in Samdrup Jongkhar, Samtse and Trashigang districts, allowing intra-district movement and limited commercial activities. Bhutan had said that it would fully vaccinate the entire country by the end of June. However, vaccine crunch in India might delay Bhutan's plan for 100% immunization. Earlier this month, Bhutanese Foreign Minister Tandi Dorji said the Indian government had assured Bhutan that it would provide the half-million AstraZeneca vaccines, known as Covishield in India, required for the second dose to achieve full immunization.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210531151256if_/https://www.livemint.com/news/india/india-requires-more-covid-vaccines-will-not-exert-pressure-for-supply-bhutan-11621693513156.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210531151256if_/https://www.livemint.com/news/india/india-requires-more-covid-vaccines-will-not-exert-pressure-for-supply-bhutan-11621693513156.html

"It has been 28 days since Dominica had its last positive case. McIntrye says this is largely due to the closure of the country’s borders, effective contact tracing and isolation, an efficient primary healthcare team, the ability to have in-country testing, compliance by the public and the team effort involving all stakeholders." Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200510035220/https://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/news/adjusting-restrictive-measures-does-not-mean-business-as-usual-says-health-minister/

23 March: “With the revelation of the first imported case, we have moved from level one to level two. Against that background, I am making a decision to suspend all classes of school from tomorrow (Monday March 23, 2020),” the prime minister announced.  Video of announcement: /web/20200421012143/https://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/news/covid-19-skerrit-suspends-classes-asks-elderly-and-medically-vulnerable-to-stay-home/

The Prime Minister held a news conference on 23 Mar 2020 and asked anyone over age 70 to stay home.   ” I am asking all persons over the age of 70 years old or any person who has an underlying that is not being managed properly to stay at home and minimize contact with the general public,”   https://web.archive.org/web/20201208184715/https://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/news/covid-19-skerrit-suspends-classes-asks-elderly-and-medically-vulnerable-to-stay-home/    The government website now lists recommendations as well, so I am leaving this as in place from 23 March 2020 onward.   Recommendations:   Keep the elderly home to reduce their risk of getting sick.  To protect the elderly against COVID19, limit visitors, especially those that are sick.  To protect against COVID19 keep elderly in a well ventilated room.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201028144106/https://dominica.gov.dm/tips-to-protect-self-family

28 March: All air and sea ports shall, except in relation to air; and sea cargo, remain closed to the arrival of aircraft or ships or other vessels carrying passengers. Then extended by State of Emergency until May 11  https://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/news/breaking-news-dominica-imposes-curfew-as-it-tightens-measures-to-fight-coronavirus/      Please note, there is evidence that before the ban there were screening measures. However, I cannot find any evidence for dates. I am assuming this was at least from the first case.

STATE OF EMERGENCY DECLARED  People should not leave their homes unless for accessing or providing essential services  https://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/breaking-news-state-of-emergency-declared-in-dominica/    Now extended up to May 11

On 1 April, Dominica announced a State of Emergency with curfew between 6pm to 6am on weekdays and total curfew during weekends. Under this, no person shall host or attend any public or private events.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200427194329/https://dominicanewsonline.com/news/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/SRO-No.-15-Emergency-Powers-Curfew-Order-2020.pdf.pdf    On 6 April, the state of emergency was extended for another three months and the curfew restrictions another 21 days past April 20th.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200427193911/https://www.dominicavibes.dm/news-263824/

On 1 April, Dominica announced a State of Emergency with curfew between 6pm to 6am on weekdays and total curfew during weekends. Under this, no person shall host or attend -  (a) a private party which includes any person from outside of the immediate household of the house occupant; (b) a recreational or competitive sporting event; (c) a wedding which hosts five or more persons other than the bride, bridegroom, official witnesses and the marriage officer; (d) any social event; (e) a funeral, except ten members of the immediate family and at least one    officiant and essential mortuary staff; or (f) a meeting of a fraternal society, private or social club  or civic association or organisation  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200427194329/https://dominicanewsonline.com/news/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/SRO-No.-15-Emergency-Powers-Curfew-Order-2020.pdf.pdf    On 6 April, the state of emergency was extended for another three months and the curfew restrictions another 21 days past April 20th.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200427193911/https://www.dominicavibes.dm/news-263824/

12. (1) No person shall offer for hire or seek to travel on -  (a) anymotoromnibus,unlessthereisorwouldbenot more than one person per row in the motor omnibus;  (b) any hiring car or taxi, unless there is not more than one person per row in the vehicle;  (c) no person other than the driver shall occupy the front seats of any vehicle for hire and no person shall sit immediately behind another.  https://dominicanewsonline.com/news/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/SRO-No.-15-Emergency-Powers-Curfew-Order-2020.pdf.pdf

On 1 April, Dominica announced a State of Emergency with curfew between 6pm to 6am on weekdays and total curfew during weekends. 1) Prime Minister Skerrit has said that part of a $14US million donation to Dominica from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will be used to bring some relief to citizens who have lost their jobs due to the effects of COVID-19 and to support persons with small businesses. However, this has so far only been an announcement and no details about how much will be given to whom has yet been disclosed.  /web/20200507030637/https://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/news/covid-19-pm-skerrit-says-part-of-imf-funds-to-be-used-for-unemployment-relief/    2) /web/20200507025055/https://www.dominicavibes.dm/business-264346/  Director of the Dominica Social Security, Janice Jean Jacques Thomas revealed on Thursday with great sadness that the proposal to combine $8m from the DSS and an initial $9.5m from government to provide an unemployment relief package was rejected.

"Dominica eases anti-coronavirus restrictions: the ease of restrictions means that appliance and electronic shops and clothing and textile shops can reopen for business, however they must ensure that staff and customers wear face masks, physical distancing protocols are enforced as well as hand sanitization upon entry to and exit from the business place. (...) Bars, night clubs, game shops, hair salons, barber shops, sulphur spas, schools, churches, gyms, manicure and pedicure shops remain closed pending further review on May 11, 2020." Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200510032514/https://www.eturbonews.com/571939/dominica-official-covid-19-tourism-update-3/

"Access to beaches and rivers will be granted for stress management from 8 am to 5 pm Mondays to Saturdays; however there shall be no picnics, barbecues, loud music, parties or consumption of alcohol at beaches or rivers. Groups of not more than 10 persons will be allowed and physical distancing must be maintained." Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200510032514/https://www.eturbonews.com/571939/dominica-official-covid-19-tourism-update-3/

Dominica’s borders are closed. International and domestic flights are suspended until?further notice and there are currently no commercial options available to leave Dominica; Borders and airports will open for nationals and residents on 15 July, and for non nationals on 7 August. Arrival health protocols will be in place. See https://web.archive.org/web/20200706193639/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/dominica

Borders and airports will open for nationals and residents on 15 July, and for non-nationals on 7 August. Arrival health protocols* will be in place.    * 1. All travellers must obtain a negative COVID-19 test (PCR) result recorded 24 to 72 hours before arriving in Dominica.  2. Travellers must complete an online questionnaire at least 24 hours in advance and show their clearance to travel.  3. Upon arrival, travellers will undergo a series of checks, including a rapid test.  4. If a traveller presents any signals deemed unsafe, such as a positive test result, they will be quarantined at a government facility or a certified hotel.    Sources:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200812234938/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/dominica/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20200903144532/https://www.traveloffpath.com/dominica-reopening-borders-for-tourism-august-7th/

"Entry to Dominica  Borders and the Douglas Charles airport are now open for nationals and non-nationals arriving in Dominica.    Screening on arrival  Arrival protocols are in place. Arriving passengers must complete an online questionnaire 24 hours before arrival, and have a PCR swab test with a negative result taken up to 72 hours before arrival. A Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT) will be taken on arrival. If the RDT is negative, then the traveller must self-isolate in a government operated or government certified facility for five days before having a further PCR test. If the RDT is positive, then a further PCR swab test will be carried out. This will be at the traveller’s expense.    If the PCR test is positive a mandatory 14 day quarantine will be necessary, in a government facility for which fees will be charged."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200917071430/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/dominica/entry-requirements

A school was forced to close because of covid exposure:    " The Dominica government has ordered the closure of a secondary school, the mandatory wearing of masks and the banning of mass events, as the island recorded eight new cases of the coronavirus (COVID-19) on Friday, pushing its total to date to 50.    Education Minister Octavia Alfred said that the decision to temporary shutdown the Isiah Thomas Secondary School (ITSS) in St, Joseph became necessary after a teacher at the institution tested positive for the virus.    “It has been confirmed that a staff member…has tested positive for the COVID-19 virus. The teacher is presently admitted at the COVID isolation facility. Ministry of Health officials have been at the school carrying out testing on staff members and students.    “The Ministry of Education is offering support to the entire staff and student body as we continue to follow directives from the Ministry of Health,” she said, adding that all relevant stakeholders, including the Dominica Association of Teachers have been made aware of the situation.    ‘As part of our precautionary measures, ITSS will be closed until November 6. We are hopeful that school will resume by November 9, 2020,” she added."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201123193643/https://www.caribbeannationalweekly.com/caribbean-breaking-news-featured/secondary-school-closes-as-dominica-records-increased-cases-of-covid/

Protocols updated 18 Nov 2020 - https://web.archive.org/web/20201208174918/https://dominica.gov.dm/images/documents/Travelprotocols_Portrait_rv8_Nov8.pdf.     There are four levels - CARICOM Bubble, Low Risk, Medium Risk, High Risk.     High Risk (most restrictive) must:   Submit a health questionnaire.   Upload a negative PCR test that is from the last 24-72 hours prior to arrival.   Get a Rapid Diagnostic Test upon arrival.   If positive, must get PCR test immediately and will be quarantined in government facility.   If negative, will be quarantined for 5 days.   After 5 days another PCR test is administered.   If positive, will be quarantined in government facility.   If negative, can be medically cleared.

According to the Director of Communication and spokesperson for the Presidency, Milagros Germán, “Regarding the gathering of people, it has been prohibited for more than 10 people to gather in public and private spaces for public use. This means that in these spaces more than 10 people can coincide at the same time, but they cannot gather in groups larger than that amount, as would happen in a shopping plaza, a transport station or a park ”.    The same restriction applies to establishments such as restaurants and bars, where tables cannot be occupied by more than 10 people and always respecting the sanitary protocols of the sector, such as not exceeding 70% of the total capacity of the premises. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221140355/https://presidencia.gob.do/noticias/la-portavoz-de-la-presidencia-detalla-el-alcance-de-las-medidas-del-toque-de-queda     However, there is an application form that needs to be filled if one intends to host a gathering of between 50 and 199 people. At the press conference held in the Green Room of the National Palace, together with the legal consultant of the Executive Power, Antoliano Peralta Romero, the presidential spokesperson referred to the mode of curfew hours and the limits of meetings in public and private spaces for public use.    "After the concerns expressed by some sectors of society, we have deemed it pertinent to make the following clarifications regarding the new social distancing measures adopted by the Government this December 15 through Decree 698-20," said Germán.      Here are the details:    "Now we have two different hours for the curfew, depending on the locality. On the one hand, in the National District and the provinces of Santo Domingo, Santiago, Duarte, La Vega and Puerto Plata this applies every day from 7:00 pm to 5:00 am ”, explained Germán.      While, in the rest of the country, the curfew applies from Monday to Friday from 9:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. and Saturdays, Sundays and holidays from 7:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m.     The spokesperson for the Presidency clarified the limitations of the new measures in relation to transfer to homes. “At these times that we have indicated, all curfew restrictions begin to apply, including the closure of public spaces, with the only exception that those days and places in which the curfew begins at 7: 00 pm, a two-hour grace period has been granted, that is, until 9:00 pm with the exclusive purpose that people can move quietly home, without the anguish that they will be detained for reasons beyond their control, such as the traffic jams that usually take place in hours close to curfew ”.    He added: “Regarding the gathering of people, it has been prohibited for more than 10 people to gather in public and private spaces for public use. This means that in these spaces more than 10 people can coincide at the same time, but they cannot gather in groups larger than that amount, as would happen in a shopping plaza, a transport station or a park ”.    The same restriction applies to establishments such as restaurants and bars, where tables cannot be occupied by more than 10 people and always respecting the sanitary protocols of the sector, such as not exceeding 70% of the total capacity of the premises.      “Finally, we wish to highlight that all the traffic exceptions during the curfew hours that we had previously, such as those relating to doctors and nurses and other health personnel, the one relating to international passengers heading or they return from the airport or the operators of vehicles dedicated to the distribution of food, supplies, fuels and other essential products, among other cases that can be detailed in article 4 of Decree 698-20, "he said.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221140355/https://presidencia.gob.do/noticias/la-portavoz-de-la-presidencia-detalla-el-alcance-de-las-medidas-del-toque-de-queda
There are no known restrictions to movement. Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221134212/https://do.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

According to the UK government's website on travel to Dominica, arrival protocols are in place. Arriving passengers must complete an online questionnaire 24 hours before arrival, and have a PCR swab test with a negative result taken up to 72 hours before arrival. This result must be uploaded and submitted with the questionnaire so that your arrival can be approved by email from the Dominican Ministry of Health. Without this email you will not be allowed to board the flight coming into Dominica.    A pinprick Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT) will be taken on arrival. If the RDT is negative, then the traveller must self-isolate in a government operated or government certified facility for five days before having a further PCR test. If the RDT is positive, then a further PCR swab test will be carried out. This will be at the traveller’s expense. Further information can be found via the Dominica Hotel and Tourist Association certified booking line at +1 (767) 615-0551.    If the PCR test is positive a mandatory 14 day quarantine will be necessary, in a government facility for which fees will be charged.    The results of the second PCR test are likely to take at least 48 hours. Once a negative test is received the next seven days can be spent at an uncertified premises but the traveller should remain inside and monitor their temperature. Managed tourist activities are possible with strict supervision from certified operators.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221141514/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/dominica/entry-requirements

There is the Livelihood Grant Assistance Scheme by the government. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221222351/https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSc1XY3xSfvUB-Qac6nYSm7_4do4WnMKoNzGSPp3bINJPWTiBw/viewform?vc=0&c=0&w=1&flr=0

There was a price of petroleum products released in September. This notice is valid till December 31st, 2020. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221224021/https://dominica.gov.dm/notices/1121-price-regualtion-petroleum-products-effective-september-21-2020

There is a public campaign and government officials readily canvas for support of the wearing of protective gear. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221142001/https://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/news/police-reiterate-warning-against-mass-gatherings-minister-refuses-to-confirm-or-deny-talk-of-more-stringent-measures/

According to the US Embassy in Dominica's website, The Dominican Republic has local capacity to diagnose COVID-19 through the National Public Health Laboratory and private laboratories.  The Dominican Republic created a national hotline for questions relating to COVID-19 if you have been exposed or are experiencing severe symptoms.  Call *462 for further instructions, but note that English-speaking operators are limited.    Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20201221134212/https://do.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/    The rapid tests are free and the PCR test costs $40. Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221230041/https://discoverdominica.com/en/travel-advisory-for-dominica

There seems to be a rigorous contact tracing measure. It was mentioned here. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221230601/https://thecaribbeannewsnow.com/dominica-records-seven-new-covid-19-cases-as-it-intensifies-contact-tracing/

It is mandatory in public spaces with a fine of up to $75.   Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221142001/https://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/news/police-reiterate-warning-against-mass-gatherings-minister-refuses-to-confirm-or-deny-talk-of-more-stringent-measures/    Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221134212/https://do.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

On the 14th of October, 2020, there was a statement by MSP stating that it has already started actions to prepare the country for the application of the vaccine against COVID-19, of which the Government has committed a sufficient amount as soon as it is available .    The Vice Minister of Collective Health, Dr. Ivelisse Acosta explained that an international consultancy has been hired to design the logistics for the application of the vaccine and determine the equipment and training needs of the health service personnel who will work in this program.    He said that these tasks began last Friday and that first of all all people who work in the health service, the elderly and people with comorbidity (diabetes, high blood pressure and others) will be vaccinated.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221231059/https://coronavirusrd.gob.do/2020/10/14/msp-inicio-acciones-para-preparar-el-pais-para-aplicacion-de-la-vacuna-contra-el-covid-19/

There is social assistance also available for people over 70 who do not have pension. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221231608/https://www.caribbeannationalweekly.com/caribbean-breaking-news-featured/world-bank-to-provide-income-support-for-dominicans/

No carnival celebration is allowed.   Acting Chief of Police, Lincoln Corbette says as a result of the cancellation of Carnival 2021, there will be no street jump up throughout the island: "Permissions have not been granted to anyone to host any event over the carnival weekend".   http://web.archive.org/web/20210222202458/https://www.dominicavibes.dm/featured-268514/

The Minister of National Security announced that "no gatherings of more than 10 or more persons in a public place including gathering at a camp for religious institutions or other purposes".   This does not include a gathering of persons who are members of the same household; a gathering at a religious institution; a gathering at the supermarket, shops, or other retail establishments for the purpose of purchasing groceries; a gathering at the restaurant for the purpose of dining on the premises; and a gathering authorized by the Chief of Police.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210222202458/https://www.dominicavibes.dm/featured-268514/

As of 7 June 2021, authorities in Dominica ease certain COVID-19 travel requirements for fully vaccinated individuals (consider fully vaccinated individuals as those who received the final dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine more than two weeks before entering Dominica).  These individuals must follow the following guidelines to enter the country, regardless of their country of origin:  - Submit a health questionnaire online at least 24 hours before arrival in Dominica.  - Proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken within 24-72 hours before arrival.  - Upon arrival, they will undergo a health assessment and enter a government-operated quarantine facility or an approved property for at least 48 hours. On day two, they will take another COVID-19 test and remain in quarantine until obtaining the results; if negative, the quarantine may end; if positive, authorities will transport them to a COVID-19 isolation unit.    Persons who are not fully vaccinated must also take a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test within 24-72 hours before departure for Dominica, submit the health questionnaire online at least 24 hours before arrival, and undergo a health assessment upon arrival. Additional requirements for unvaccinated travelers vary depending on their country of origin.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614105901/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/487686/dominica-authorities-ease-restrictions-for-travelers-fully-vaccinated-against-covid-19-as-of-june-7-update-18

Authorities in Dominica are maintaining travel restrictions in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Under the measures, fully vaccinated persons and unvaccinated individuals must quarantine for different periods of time.  Approved vaccines include those by AstraZeneca, Janssen, Moderna, Pfizer, and Sinopharm.    Fully vaccinated individuals must follow the following guidelines to enter the country, regardless of their country of origin:  Submit a health questionnaire online at least 24 hours before arrival in Dominica. Submit proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken 24-72 hours before arrival online. Present a notification of health clearance to travel. Present proof of vaccination upon arrival. Upon arrival, all vaccinated persons will undergo a health assessment and enter a government-operated quarantine facility or an approved property for at least 48 hours.    Persons who are not fully vaccinated must also take a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test within 24-72 hours before departure for Dominica, submit the health questionnaire online at least 24 hours before arrival, and undergo a health assessment upon arrival. Additional requirements for unvaccinated travelers vary depending on their country of origin:  - High-risk Countries: Travelers will undergo mandatory quarantine at a government-operated facility or a certified private property for a minimum of five to seven days.  - Low and medium risk Countries: Upon arrival, travelers will undergo a health assessment and testing for COVID-19 at the airport with an antigen test. Travelers testing negative can leave the airport; those testing positive will take an additional PCR test and wait for the results at a government-approved facility.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210715160532/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/498761/dominica-authorities-maintain-travel-requirements-as-of-july-6-update-19

Since 7 July 2021, the IMF website was updated to state that "income support for heads of families and single persons who are currently unemployed,  was extended through June 2021". No source was mentioned to confirm this information. The last official statement from the Government of Dominica on this topic was on 5 May 2021, and stated that the eligibility period for income support ended on 30 April 2021. And the official form that had to be filled to apply for income support is no longer available on the Government Web Portal. The Government of the Republic of Mauritius is providing income support for the months of March and April 2020 (extension provided for April) to both formal and informal sector workers through two schemes: a. the Government Wage Assistance Scheme (GWAS) for employees who would become unemployed on a temporary basis and b. the Self-Employed Assistance Scheme (SEAS) for those employed in informal sectors or self-employed.  All companies in Mauritius can apply for Wage Assistance subsidy to alleviate the employee cost for the month of March ranging from  15 days basic wage bill to MUR 12,500 per employee. Workers from the informal sector, i.e self-employed not registered with the revenue authority will get 50% of the prevailing minimum wage if they register with the revenue authority during the COVID19 lockdown. Since this is calculated based on basic wage in case of formal sector and the minimum wage in case of the informal sector, on average, it might be less than 50% of the monthly income of the employees/workers. https://web.archive.org/web/20200626194901/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 https://web.archive.org/web/20200627102230/https://www.edbmauritius.org/media/3163/communique_extension_of_gwas_and_seas.pdf KPMG Mauritius government response: http://archive.vn/YjFAf

The Covid-19 has infected a total of 107 Mauritians as at now. The number of cases has risen, over the past 24 hours, from 102 to reach 107, with five new cases confirmed. One hundred and twenty-eight tests have been conducted since yesterday. Mauritius has a reserve of 20 000 polymerase chain reaction (PCR tests), and 100 000 tests will reach the country this week.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200408220016/https://allafrica.com/stories/202003300477.html

Contact tracing has enabled the detection of more than 58% of the cases that have been tested positive to the Covid-19. A total number of 953 contact tracing has been carried out as at 28 March 2020 with 72 positive cases. Out of the 107 cases, 39 are women and 68 are men. Two deaths have also been registered since the start of the outbreak of the virus in the country.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200408220016/https://allafrica.com/stories/202003300477.html

Support to Households -  Mauritian households impacted by COVID-19 may request their commercial banks for a moratorium of 6 months on capital repayments on their existing household loans as from the 1st April 2020. In addition, for households earning a combined monthly basic salary of up to Rs 50,000 the Bank of Mauritius will bear the interest payable for the period 1st April 2020 to 30th June 2020 on their outstanding household loans with commercial banks. Government announced that a plan was being made in 'regard the easing of confinement restrictions as from the 15 May 2020.'    https://web.archive.org/web/20200506155118/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Government-is-planning-for-a-strategic-phased-resumption-of-economic-activities,-says-PM.aspx

Support to households remains - six-month moratorium on household loans at commercial banks, while BOM will bear interest payments for households with the lowest income. See:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200626194901/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 KPMG Mauritius government response: http://archive.vn/YjFAf

It seems like contract tracing is comprehensive rather than limited. Since the time the number of cases climbed steadily and reached 128 on 30 March, health services prioritised contact tracing to identify people to test – that is, people who had been in physical contact with infected and identified patients – while anybody who had been quarantined and showed symptoms suggestive of COVID-19 infection was also tested. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20200521205121/https://voxeu.org/article/mauritian-response-covid-19

https://web.archive.org/web/20200517204302/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/03/coronavirus-travel-restrictions-border-shutdowns-country-200318091505922.html  As of 13 May.  Non-resident foreign nationals are not allowed to transit or enter Mauritius. Airline crew will be isolated in their hotel rooms.

As from 15 May 2020, more businesses will be allowed to operate, namely bakeries, hardware stores and fish markets and the opening hours of supermarkets will be extended to 20 00 hrs. Banks will continue to operate under strict hygiene protocol. Moreover, work from home will also be encouraged for officers. Dentists, opticians, vegetable planters and fishermen, amongst others, can also return to their normal activities while respecting strict hygiene measures.See: https://web.archive.org/web/20200521205817/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Covid-19-Curfew-extended-to-1st-June-and-schools-to-remain-closed-till-1st-August.aspx

The borders remain closed to international arrivals, except for repatriation flights for nationals who were stranded abroad. See https://web.archive.org/web/20200521205121/https://voxeu.org/article/mauritian-response-covid-19

Places of worship may also reopen. However, beaches, nightclubs and cinemas will remain closed along with the borders.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200601125334/https://www.africanews.com/2020/05/30/mauritius-coronavirus-no-new-case-in-8-days-amid-lockdown-extension//

The curfew in Mauritius imposed due to Covid-19 was lifted on Saturday 30 May 2020, at midnight but some businesses are required to remain closed. "Trades such as supermarkets will be able to operate on a normal hour basis without having to necessarily respect the alphabetical order rule. Restaurants, coffee shops, food courts, shops, arcades and shopping malls will be allowed to resume operation under certain sanitary conditions.  Food and vegetable markets will be allowed to open as per the instructions of Municipality and District Council...Beaches, fairs, cinemas and nightclubs will remain closed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200617152934/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Covid-19-Mauritius-to-lift-curfew-on-30-May-2020,-at-midnight,-says-PM.aspx

"Individual sporting activities will be permitted under certain sanitary conditions.  Places of worship will be allowed to receive devotees.  Beaches, fairs, cinemas and nightclubs will remain closed.  Collective sporting activities, socio-cultural gatherings, sporting and cultural events will not be authorised.  However, this decision will be reviewed in two weeks time."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200617152934/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Covid-19-Mauritius-to-lift-curfew-on-30-May-2020,-at-midnight,-says-PM.aspx

There is no specific mention of gathering size in the government report, but given what it mentions in regards to what is still banned, I think a 3 is warranted. All companies in Mauritius can apply for Wage Assistance subsidy to alleviate the employee cost for the month of March ranging from  15 days basic wage bill to MUR 12,500 per employee. Workers from the informal sector, i.e self employed not registered with the revenue authority will get 50% of the prevailing minimum wage if they register with the revenue authority during the COVID19 lockdown. Priority sectors for assistance are travel and tourism sector, export-oriented enterprises, ICT/BPO sector, SMEs and other sectors of the economy, who become technically unemployed on a temporary basis due to the impact of the Coronavirus. KPMG archived government and institution measures: http://archive.vn/YjFAf

Communication strategy: The three sub-themes emerging under this main theme are: (1) To engage the population, (2) To combat the spread of false information, and (3) To control the outbreak. In a bid to efficiently communicate important information related to the local COVID-19 outbreak to the general population during the national lockdown, a National Communication Committee on COVID-19 was set up. This committee was led by the Prime Minister and its team members were on alert on a 24/7 basis.  https://archive.vn/mjXdA
Covid-19: Mauritius rolls out mass testing Government website https://archive.vn/QTC49

"After 47 days without any new local Covid-19 case, all economic and social activities can now resume and we should be proud of the way we have tackled the situation, stated the Prime Minister, Mr Pravind Kumar Jugnauth, this evening, in a press conference at the Treasury Building in Port Louis.  The Prime Minister announced that following the Cabinet Meeting today, decision has been taken for the lift of all business and activity lockdowns ordered earlier to cope with the Covid-19, as from Monday 15 June 2020. Consequently, beaches, markets, gyms, parks, Village Halls, Community Centres, cinema and other public places will now be accessible to the public but the wearing of masks will still be compulsory."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200617154020/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Covid-19-We-should-be-proud-of-the-way-we-have-tackled-the-situation,-says-PM.aspx

Consequently, beaches, markets, gyms, parks, Village Halls, Community Centres, cinema and other public places will now be accessible to the public but the wearing of masks will still be compulsory."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200617154020/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/Covid-19-We-should-be-proud-of-the-way-we-have-tackled-the-situation,-says-PM.aspx
